abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about a
            successful conservation and socio-economic model in Addo
            Elephant National Park (AENP) in South Africa. The AENP lies
            to the north of the city of Port Elizabeth, in South
            Africa’s Eastern Cape Province. The park is one of the most
            diverse conservation areas in Southern Africa which contain
            rich marine ecosystems. AENP was one of South Africa’s most
            economically challenged provinces, faced with high rates of
            illiteracy and unemployment. Persistent poverty, unabated
            over the years by subsistence livestock farming, posed a
            threat to the region’s biodiversity and hastened
            desertification as communities struggled to eke out a living
            from their surrounding natural resource base. The
            International Bank for Reconstruction and Development
            provided a grant from the Global Environment Facility as
            well as the expertise and technical knowledge of several
            experts. As a result, income from tourism became significant
            economic benefit to the region. Populations of one of the
            most threatened species in the AENP and in all of Africa,
            the black rhinoceros population, continues to increase
            within the park. Employment amongst local businesses showed
            steady increase resulting in the creation of new jobs by new
            private sector enterprises The project has contributed to a
            revitalization of the local environment and economy by
            providing an opportunity for local communities to benefit
            financially from the removal of invasive alien vegetation,
            and serves as a benchmark for further future community
            development projects.
